timeline.message: Adding ONWindowExpiration in DoFnRunner, Adding a test case in ParDoTest

timeline.bodyText:
What do timestamp and timeDomain mean in this context?
Also presumably you do want to be able to access the key in onWindowExpiration
timeline.author: reuvenlax
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -52,6 +52,12 @@ void onTimer(
    */
   void finishBundle();
 
+  /**
+   * Calls a {@link DoFn DoFn's} {@link DoFn.OnWindowExpiration @OnWindowExpiration} method and
+   * performs additional task, such as extracts a value saved in a state before garbage collection.
+   */
+  void onWindowExpiration(BoundedWindow window, Instant timestamp, TimeDomain timeDomain);

replies.bodyText:
@reuvenlax timestamp added to keep the time of outputs from OnWindowExpiration. This would be window.maxTimestamp()
timeDomain removed
replies.author: rehmanmuradali

timeline.bodyText: Why is this based on OnTimerContext?
timeline.author: reuvenlax

timeline.bodyText: We also seem to set GC timers in ReduceFnRunner.java. @kennknowles do you know why we have both?
timeline.author: reuvenlax

               "",

-              cleanupTime,

timeline.bodyText: this should be window.maxTimestamp() + allowedLateness I think?  cleanupTime here is passed in as maxTimestamp + allowedLateness + 1ms
timeline.author: steveniemitz
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -591,7 +591,7 @@ public void flushState() {
               timerId,
               "",
               cleanupTime,
-              cleanupTime,
+              window.maxTimestamp(),

timeline.bodyText: Wondering if we need to expose timers here, as I don't see how it makes sense to create a new timer in an expired window.
timeline.author: reuvenlax
reuvenlax

timeline.bodyText: I think this change is incorrect. Why was it necessary?
timeline.author: reuvenlax
rehmanmuradali

replies.bodyText: Why do we need the output timestamp in onWindowExpiration?
replies.author: reuvenlax

replies.bodyText: I think elements that are output on OnWindowExpiration would have a timestamp equals the output timestamp of the GC timer that's why we need it here. In the case of a window of Instant [0-10), 10 would be GC timer with an output timestamp of 9. So elements that are output from onWindowExpiration would have a timestamp of 9. @reuvenlax
replies.author: rehmanmuradali

timeline.message:
Merge branch 'master' into feature/BEAM-1589

# Conflicts:
#	runners/spark/build.gradle
#	runners/spark/job-server/build.gradle
Deletion of System Timer + Test updates

timeline.bodyText: I want to avoid the performance regression of setting a watermark hold if not needed.  Make the outputTimestamp be a parameter to this function, and pass it in only if the DoFn has an onWindowExpiration (SimpleParDoFn has the DoFnSignature so you should be able to tell there).
timeline.author: reuvenlax
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -591,7 +595,7 @@ public void flushState() {
               timerId,
               "",
               cleanupTime,
-              cleanupTime,
+              cleanupTime.minus(1L),

timeline.bodyText: I think we should only do this if there is a hold to delete.
timeline.author: reuvenlax

timeline.message: Setting and deleting hold if OnWindowExpiration is present
